calculator

Class UNumber

  • java.lang.Object
    • calculator.UNumber
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<UNumber>

    public class UNumber
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<UNumber>

    Title: UNumber Class, a component of the Unlimited Precision Math Package.

    Description: A demonstration package to show the notion of a package and to exercise array usage

    Copyright: Lynn Robert Carter, MD.Ashfak Â© 2014

    Version:
    1.02a Addition of code to support quality improvements, and the removal of the div2 method, 1.01 The initial version plus an improved add/sub, normalize, div, div2, lessThan, greaterThan, abs, and compareTo, 1.03 The previous versions plus an improved squareRoot method using Newton Raphon Method, significantFigure and isPositive methods to find out the position of the decimal and the positivity respectively, 1.04 linked with the calculator project, 4.0.6 2020-09-10 The JavaFX-based GUI for the implementation of a UNumber calculator with Units
    Author:
    Lynn Robert Carter, MD.Ashfak

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      UNumber()
      This default constructor sets up a 20 digit number with a value of zero
      UNumber(double v)
      This constructor takes a double and creates a UNumber from it.

      This constructor creates a variable length number based on an integer input value

      This constructor creates a variable length number based on a long integer input value
      UNumber(java.lang.String str, int dec, boolean sign)
      This constructor creates a number based on a digit sequence in a string, a power of ten, and a sign
      UNumber(java.lang.String str, int dec, boolean sign, int size)
      This constructor creates a number based on a digit sequence in a string, a power of ten, a sign, and a size constant.
      UNumber(UNumber that)
      This is a copy constructor
      UNumber(UNumber that, int size)
      This is a copy constructor where the size of the new value is specified
      UNumber(UNumber that, UNumber another)
      This constructor creates a potentially unnormalized value (there maybe leading zeros) with enough space in the mantissa array to hold all of the significant digits of both input parameters at the same time.

      • UNumber

        public UNumber(java.lang.String str,
               int dec,
               boolean sign)
        This constructor creates a number based on a digit sequence in a string, a power of ten, and a sign
        Parameters:
        str - The string specifies the digit sequence and it's length is the number of significant digits
        dec - This is the characteristic (the power of 10)
        sign - The sign

      • UNumber

        public UNumber(java.lang.String str,
               int dec,
               boolean sign,
               int size)
        This constructor creates a number based on a digit sequence in a string, a power of ten, a sign, and a size constant. If the size is larger than the constant sequence, the extra positions are filled with zero. If the size is less than the digit sequence, the excess digits are discarded.
        Parameters:
        str - The string specifies the digit sequence and it's length is the number of significant digits
        dec - This is the characteristic (the power of 10)
        sign - The sign
        size - The number of significant digits

        This is a copy constructor
        Parameters:

      • UNumber

        public UNumber(UNumber that,
               int size)
        This is a copy constructor where the size of the new value is specified
        Parameters:

        size - This parameter specifies the size of the other parameter

      • UNumber

        public UNumber(UNumber that,
               UNumber another)
        This constructor creates a potentially unnormalized value (there maybe leading zeros) with enough space in the mantissa array to hold all of the significant digits of both input parameters at the same time. It initializes the new number to the value of the first parameter. This constructor is used to align the decimal points of two numbers.
        Parameters:
        that - This parameter is used to initialize the number
        another - This one helps determine the how many significant digits to use

      • UNumber

        public UNumber(double v)
        This constructor takes a double and creates a UNumber from it. The result is rounded to a 14 significant digit result.
        Parameters:
        v - This parameter will be converted to UNumber

      • isZero

        public boolean isZero()
        If the first digit of the UNumber is zero, the value must be zero as these values are normalized.
        Returns:
        true if the value is zero, else false.

      • add

        public void add(UNumber that)
        The Addition operation adds the second operand to this object's value (this = this + that) The code implements the addition in a very simplistic manner, sacrificing speed and space for a very simple algorithm that mirrors how people do addition by hand.
        Parameters:
        that - The second operand that is added to this object's value

      • sub

        public void sub(UNumber that)
        The subtract operation negates the second operand and uses the add operator (this = this - that) The code uses a temporary for the second operand so the callers second operand is not changed
        Parameters:
        that - The second operand that is subtracted from the value of this object's value

      • mpy

        public void mpy(UNumber that)
        The multiply operation implements multiplication is the traditional, by hand-hand manner, where each digit of the multiplicand is multiplied by each digit of the multiplier and adding into the proper digit of the product using the index of the multiplier digit as the base for the summation. Since we have unlimited number of digits, the intermediate results can become arbitrarily large, so the carry must be resolved into the product after each digit multiplication.
        Parameters:
        that - The multiplier

      • div

        public void div(UNumber that)
        The divide operation implements division by means of repeated subtraction, producing as many significant digits in the quotient as in the dividend (this object) and the quotient replaces the dividend. This is a faster algorithm than the simpler Div2 below. This algorithm assumes the numbers are normalized.
        Parameters:
        that - The divisor

      • lessThan

        public boolean lessThan(UNumber that)
        This lessThan routine tries to avoid doing a subtraction in order to do things faster. Therefore checks of sign bits, then the decimal points, and then the first digits are done before falling into a subtract as a last resort. If one value is negative and the other is positive, there is no need to go any further. If they are of the same size, but the characteristics of the normalized values are not the same, there is no need to go any further. Given the same size and the same characteristic for normalized numbers, if the first digit can resolve the issue, try that. Only in the case where the signs, characteristics, *and* the first digits are the same do we resort to subtraction and a check of the sign bit.
        Parameters:
        that - The right operand in the "this lessThan that" relational test
        Returns:
        boolean true if this is indeed less than that

      • greaterThan

        public boolean greaterThan(UNumber that)
        This greaterThan routine tries to avoid doing a subtraction in order to do things faster. This code follows the same process as the less than code above
        Parameters:
        that - The right operand in the "this greaterThan that" relational test
        Returns:
        boolean true if this is indeed greater than that

      • abs

        public void abs()
        This absolute value routine sets the sign bit true which has the same effect of doing an absolute value on this

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(UNumber that)
        This compareTo routine satisfies the "Comparable" interface
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<UNumber>
        Parameters:
        that - is being compare here with the UNumber which is used to call the function
        Returns:
        it returns 1 if that is smaller, -1 if that is greater and 0 if that is equal to this

        the Double equivalent of the UNumber

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        i which is the index number of the decimal point's location in the string

        public boolean isPositive(java.lang.String str)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • squareRoot

        public UNumber squareRoot(UNumber originalValue)
        This squareRoot routine finds out the square root of a UNumber. This function follows Newton Raphons method to find the square root
        Parameters:
        originalValue - is a UNumber whose square root is being calculated here
        Returns:
        temp is the final result or the square root of the input UNumber
